awd_abstract_narration:
There are many Earth processes besides earthquakes that cause ground movement. In particular, turbulent river motions, and sediment transported by these motions, sea ice-ocean wave interactions, subglacial water flow, and hydrothermal activity all cause ground motion that can be observed with sensitive seismic instrumentation. This project makes use of such unique seismic observations to quantitatively better understand these Earth processes, many of which are extremely complex and poorly observed yet important both geophysically and societally. These processes also share similar basic mechanics involving the interactions of fluids with solids, and this project will result in new insights into how fluid and solid mechanics combine in nature to produce the diverse phenomena described. This interdisciplinary work helps improve flood warnings, sea ice predictions, sea level rise predictions, and an understanding of induced earthquakes.

The primary goal of the project is to improve our ability to make use of seismic observations of environmental sources other than earthquakes. Improvements in applying wave propagation tools in complex environments and improvements in the interdisciplinary mechanics that governs how these sources couple seismically are the main avenues by which this goal will be attained. The new mechanics focused on here involves a better-integrated understanding of fluid-solid interactions and how these interactions combine to produce seismically observable ground motions. This is accomplished partly by analytic approximations to couple forces from turbulent eddies with nearby solids. Further semi-analytic approximations are used for wave propagation in complex media. With the primary goals accomplished, the new observations will help constrain aspects of the mechanics of these complex systems that have been difficult to observe with other techniques. This is anticipated to lead to new conceptual ideas about these systems that in turn are expected to lead to new quantitative understanding of the geophysical processes underlying the observed phenomena.

por.por_cntn:
Natural hazards such as flooding, mudslides, sea level rise, storm surge, volcanic eruptions and earthquakes are all caused by geophysical processes that are complex. Due to this complexity, which all involves physical interactions between solids and fluids, these processes are difficult to understand and measure, making it difficult to foresee the various geophysical and societal consequences. Since all of the processes are dynamic, they involve motions that can be observed by sensitive seismic instruments placed at sites not directly impacted by the associated hazards. This work focused on improving our understanding of the interdisciplinary mechanics that govern the various sources of ground motion vibrations as well as understanding how these ground motions can be measured and understood from sensors at sites that are safely away from the hazards, with the eventual goal of improving predictions and warnings of the associated hazards.

One prong of this research focused on how fast flowing water interacts with debris, boulders, and other solids to create ground shaking, both through the impact of the solid particles on the ground as well as through the stresses imparted from the fluid itself. We found that sediment transported in steep mountain rivers, mudslides caused by intense precipitation, and even eruptions of certain debris-rich magmas in volcanoes all share some basic physics in how shaking is created, but also that the physical regimes are potentially different in these different cases. Laboratory experiments confirmed our theoretical predictions over a wide range of situations, suggesting that ground vibration observations can be used to learn about flow rates, particle sizes and particle fractions in these diverse environments.

Another prong of this work focused on improving our understanding of how local ground structure near the instrument, rather than only in the source region, affects the vibration measurements. Standard wave theory used for predicting how light focuses in intensity depending on the medium it travels through can be used to predict differences in vibration intensities in the ground. Previous theory accurately explained only vertically traveling waves and now through this work both vertically and horizontally traveling waves can be predicted accurately within a semi-analytic framework. This explains why vibration intensities can vary by orders of magnitude even when the source is relatively constant. This work is useful not only for understanding geophysical processes that create small vibrations, but also for understanding large earthquakes and has led to an improvement in being able to predict the spatial variability in damaging ground motions from devastating earthquakes.

Yet another aspect of this work was to improve our understanding of the complexity of earthquakes by treating the motions of fault-zone structures statistically rather than as a large number of deterministically determined fault motions. This work built upon our understanding of how a similarly complex set of boulder impacts occurs in debris flows and found that certain aspects of the earthquake physics could be understood within the same theoretical framework. This alternative modeling approach has led to the ability to make predictions of how damaging ground motions vary between different earthquakes of similar sizes but with different amounts of complexity. Since it is not possible to deterministically model real earthquakes with significant complexity due to both our lack of knowledge and constraints in computational resources, such statistical predictions are a useful way to characterize differences given what is known about faults. Specifically, given geological fault maps, the statistical density and misalignment of faults can be measured and this in turn yields predictions about the intensity of ground motions. Tests of these predictions were found to successfully explain a factor of 10 variability in earthquake ground motions across Southern California.

On the educational side, visits were taken to AP physics classes in both Pasadena, California and Providence, Rhode Island to explain to public high school students how the physics they learned about masses oscillating on springs could be used to understand geophysical processes such as ocean waves, earthquake waves, and tsunamis. This clear application of physics to understanding the Earth opened students' eyes to potential careers that apply physics beyond the classroom and inspired them to consider quantitative physics-based Earth science fields of study. In addition, during the course of research, a number of graduate students, undergraduate students and postdoctoral researchers were educated and have gained useful research experience.
